title: File banckruptcy will get back my license?
question: im a general contractor in ca my license was suspended for unpaid bond if i file bankruptcy can i get back my license and when ones i file or at the end .
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy repayment plan,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,License suspension for traffic tickets,Construction law
answers:
I practice both bankruptcy and construction law and have dealt with this issue several times. If the only issue for your suspended license is the unpaid bond claim, the CSLB will generally reinstate your license after the cour enters discharge. A bankruptcy won't help other issues like a suspension for failure to have workers com insurance.

You should review your financial situation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to see if bankruptcy is really an option for you. In Chapter 7 bankruptcy, the trustee appointed to your case might take and sell assets that you need to run your business. An attorney can tell you if any of your business tools are at risk. In a Chapter 13, you might be in a payment plan for several years and not get your license back until then end. If the bond claim is your only debt, bankruptcy might not even make sense.

The bottom line: go see a good attorney.

The Contractors State License Board (CSLB) is a certifying state agency for contractors. I assume the CSLB pulled your license. This is a quasi-enforcement issue.

The California Business and Professions Code section 7102 will consider MONETARY obligations discharged in bankruptcy as SATISFIED for license re-issuance. However, if there are NON-monetary obligations, bankruptcy will NOT remove those conditions for re-issuance.

Given the obvious complexity of your business finances, I strongly urge you to retain a competent bankruptcy attorney to ensure a smooth transition through bankruptcy.

Good luck.
